sn35.87:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn35.87:1.2: Now at that time the venerables Sāriputta, Mahācunda, and Channa were staying on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn35.87:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Channa was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn35.87:1.4: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahācunda and said to him,
sn35.87:1.5: “Come, Reverend Cunda, let’s go to see Venerable Channa and ask about his illness.”
sn35.87:2.1: And then Sāriputta and Mahācunda went to see Channa and sat down on the seats spread out. Sāriputta said to Channa:
sn35.87:2.2: “I hope you’re keeping well, Reverend Channa; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
sn35.87:3.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.
sn35.87:3.2: The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.
sn35.87:3.4: The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
sn35.87:3.6: The winds piercing my belly are so severe, it feels like a deft butcher or their apprentice is slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
sn35.87:3.8: The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
sn35.87:3.9: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.
sn35.87:3.10: Reverend Sāriputta, I will slit my wrists. I don’t wish to live.”
sn35.87:4.2: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.
sn35.87:4.3: If you don’t have any suitable food, we’ll find it for you.
sn35.87:4.4: If you don’t have suitable medicine, we’ll find it for you.
sn35.87:4.5: If you don’t have a capable carer, we’ll find one for you.
sn35.87:4.7: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.”
sn35.87:5.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s not that I don’t have suitable food;
sn35.87:5.3: It’s not that I don’t have suitable medicine;
sn35.87:5.5: It’s not that I don’t have a capable carer;
sn35.87:5.6: I do have a capable carer.
sn35.87:5.7: Moreover, for a long time now I have served the Teacher with love, not without love.
sn35.87:5.8: For it is proper for a disciple to serve the Teacher with love, not without love.
sn35.87:5.9: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”
sn35.87:6.1: “I’d like to ask Venerable Channa about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
sn35.87:6.2: “Ask, Reverend Sāriputta. When I’ve heard it I’ll know.”
sn35.87:7.1: “Reverend Channa, do you regard the eye, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?
sn35.87:7.2: Do you regard the ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.87:7.3: mind, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn35.87:8.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, I regard the eye, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn35.87:8.2: I regard the ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.87:8.3: mind, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
sn35.87:9.1: “Reverend Channa, what have you seen, what have you directly known in these things that you regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
sn35.87:10.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, after seeing cessation, after directly knowing cessation in these things I regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
sn35.87:11.1: When he said this, Venerable Mahācunda said to Venerable Channa,
sn35.87:11.2: “So, Reverend Channa, you should pay close attention to this instruction of the Buddha whenever you can:
sn35.87:11.3: ‘For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation.
sn35.87:11.4: When there’s no agitation there is tranquility.
sn35.87:11.5: When there’s tranquility there’s no inclination.
sn35.87:11.6: When there’s no inclination, there’s no coming and going.
sn35.87:11.7: When there’s no coming and going, there’s no passing away and reappearing.
sn35.87:11.8: When there’s no passing away and reappearing, there’s no this world or world beyond or between the two.
sn35.87:11.9: Just this is the end of suffering.’”
sn35.87:12.1: And when the venerables Sāriputta and Mahācunda had given Venerable Channa this advice they got up from their seat and left.
sn35.87:12.2: Not long after those venerables had left, Venerable Channa slit his wrists.
sn35.87:13.1: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn35.87:13.2: “Sir, Venerable Channa has slit his wrists.
sn35.87:13.3: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
sn35.87:13.4: “Sāriputta, didn’t the mendicant Channa declare his blamelessness to you personally?”
sn35.87:13.5: “Sir, there is a Vajjian village named Pubbavijjhana
sn35.87:13.6: where Channa had families with whom he was friendly, intimate, and familiar.”
sn35.87:13.7: “The mendicant Channa did indeed have such families, Sāriputta.
sn35.87:13.8: But this is not enough for me to call someone ‘blameworthy’.
sn35.87:13.9: When someone lays down this body and takes up another body, I call them ‘blameworthy’.
sn35.87:13.10: But the mendicant Channa did no such thing.
sn35.87:13.11: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”
